title: How to Make Bone Broth for Your Dog At Home

steps.title: Fill a pot, crockpot, or instant pot with water, bones, and vinegar.
steps.content: Fill a pot, crockpot, or instant pot with water, bones, and vinegar. Add 3 US quarts (2.8 L) of water for every 2 pounds (32 oz) of raw bones, or pour water until the bones are covered, plus an additional 2 to 3 inches (5.1 to 7.6 cm) of water on top. Go to source Pour no more than 1 ⁄ 4 cup (59 mL) of apple cider vinegar into the mixture to create a gelatinous broth. For flavor, add in 2 sprigs of a dog-safe herb like parsley or rosemary. Apple cider vinegar can aid a dog’s digestion, reduce gas and bloating, reduce joint inflammation, and promote dental health. [2] X Research source Optionally, leave out the vinegar for a thinner, soup-like broth.

steps.title: Cover and cook the mixture on low heat for 20 to 24 hours.
steps.content: Cover and cook the mixture on low heat for 20 to 24 hours. Cover the pot with a lid and cook the mixture on low heat. steps.content: Strain out the bones and add dog-safe vegetables. Use a fine mesh strainer or a colander with small holes to strain out all the bones and cartilage. steps.title: Let the bone broth cool, put it in the fridge, and scrape off the fat.
steps.content: Let the bone broth cool, put it in the fridge, and scrape off the fat. Allow the broth to cool down to room temperature, then pop it in the fridge for 2 to 3 hours. steps.title: Add 2 to 3 spoonfuls of broth to your dog’s regular meals.
steps.content: Add 2 to 3 spoonfuls of broth to your dog’s regular meals. Generally, 2 US quarts (1,900 mL) of broth can last 1 dog for about 1 month when used every meal. 1 cup (240 mL) of bone broth typically contains about 29 calories. [19] X Research source Use this calorie calculator to see if you need to reduce your dog’s kibble to maintain a healthy weight.

steps.title: Refrigerate the broth in a mason jar or container for 3 to 4 days.
steps.content: Refrigerate the broth in a mason jar or container for 3 to 4 days. Pour the broth into a mason jar or plastic container with a tight-fitting lid and place it in the fridge. You can safely store broth in the fridge for 3 to 4 days. [20] X Research source

steps.title: Freeze the broth in ice-cube trays to store for to 2 to 3 months.
steps.content: Freeze the broth in ice-cube trays to store for to 2 to 3 months. Pouring broth into an ice-cube tray is an easy, practical way to serve broth in small portions. Give a cube to your dog by itself or add it to their meals for a tasty frozen surprise. [21] X Research source You can safely freeze broth for 2 to 3 months. [22] X Research source Optionally, pour broth into a resealable plastic bag, press out the air, and lay it flat in your freezer. After 2 hours, gently press a butter knife onto the bag to cut the broth into smaller portions you can break off when needed.
